sentences.sentence: And just as the Witch( 女巫 ) Jadis had looked different when you saw her in our world instead of in her own,
so the fruit of that mountain garden looked different too.
There were of course all sorts of colored things in the bedroom; the colored counterpane( 床单 ) on the bed, the wallpaper, the sunlight from the window, and Mother’s pretty, pale blue dressing jacket.
But the moment Digory took the Apple out of his pocket, all those things seemed to have scarcely( 几乎没有 ) any color at all.
Every one of them, even the sunlight, looked faded( 褪色的 ) and dingy( 昏暗的 ).
The brightness of the Apple threw strange lights on the ceiling( 天花板 ).
Nothing else was worth looking at; you couldn’t look at anything else.
And the smell of the Apple of Youth was as if there was a window in the room that opened on Heaven.
“Oh, darling( 亲爱的 ), how lovely,” said Digory’s Mother.
“You will eat it, won’t you? Please,” said Digory.
“I don’t know what the Doctor would say,” she answered. “But really—I almost feel as if I could.”
He peeled( 削皮 ) it and cut it up and gave it to her piece by piece.
And no sooner had she finished it than she smiled and her head sank back on the pillow( 枕头 ) and she was asleep:
a real, natural, gentle sleep, without any of those nasty( 让人讨厌的 ) drugs, which was, as Digory knew, the thing in the whole world that she wanted most.
And he was sure now that her face looked a little different.
He bent down( 弯腰 ) and kissed her very softly and stole out of the room with a beating heart; taking the core( 果核 ) of the Apple with him.
For the rest of that day, whenever he looked at the things about him, and saw how ordinary and unmagical( 普通的 ) they were,
he hardly dared to hope; but when he remembered the face of Aslan he did hope.
That evening he buried the core( 果核 ) of the Apple in the back garden.
Next morning when the Doctor made his usual visit, Digory leaned over( 伏在...上 ) the banisters( 扶手 ) to listen. He heard the Doctor come out with Aunt Letty and say:
“Miss Ketterley, this is the most extraordinary case I have known in my whole medical career( 职业生涯 ).
It is—it is like a miracle( 奇迹 ). I wouldn’t tell the little boy anything at present; we don’t want to raise any false hopes.
But in my opinion—” then his voice became too low to hear.
That afternoon he went down the garden and whistled their agreed secret signal for Polly (she hadn’t been able to get back the day before).
“What luck?” said Polly, looking over the wall. “I mean, about your Mother?”
“I think—I think it is going to be all right,” said Digory. “But if you don’t mind I’d really rather not talk about it yet. What about the rings?”
“I’ve got them all,” said Polly. “Look, it’s all right, I’m wearing gloves. Let’s bury them.”
“Yes, let’s. I’ve marked the place where I buried the core( 果核 ) of the Apple yesterday.”
Then Polly came over the wall and they went together to the place.
But, as it turned out, Digory need not have marked the place. Something was already coming up.
It was not growing so that you could see it grow as the new trees had done in Narnia; but it was already well above ground.
They got a trowel( 小铲子 ) and buried all the magic rings( 魔戒 ), including their own ones, in a circle round it.
About a week after this it was quite certain that Digory’s Mother was getting better.
About a fortnight( 两星期 ) later she was able to sit out in the garden.
And a month later that whole house had become a different place.
Aunt Letty did everything that Mother liked; windows were opened, frowsy( 肮脏的 ) curtains were drawn back to brighten up the rooms,
there were new flowers everywhere, and nicer things to eat, and the old piano was tuned( 调好音的 ) and Mother took up her singing again,
and had such games with Digory and Polly that Aunt Letty would say “I declare( 宣布 ), Mabel, you’re the biggest baby of the three.”
When things go wrong, you’ll find they usually go on getting worse for some time; but when things once start going right they often go on getting better and better.
After about six weeks of this lovely life there came a long letter from Father in India, which had wonderful news in it.
Old Great-Uncle Kirke had died and this meant, apparently, that Father was now very rich.
He was going to retire and come home from India forever and ever( 直到永远 ).
And the great big house in the country, which Digory had heard of all his life and never seen would now be their home;
the big house with the suits of armor( 盔甲 ), the stables( 马厩 ), the kennels, the river, the park, the hothouses( 温室 ), the vineries( 葡萄园 ), the woods, and the mountains behind it.
So that Digory felt just as sure as you that they were all going to live happily ever after.
But perhaps you would like to know just one or two things more.
Polly and Digory were always great friends and she came nearly every holiday to stay with them at their beautiful house in the country;
and that was where she learned to ride and swim and milk and bake and climb.
In Narnia the Beasts lived in great peace and joy and neither the Witch( 女巫 ) nor any other enemy came to trouble that pleasant land for many hundred years.
King Frank and Queen Helen and their children lived happily in Narnia and their second son became King of Archenland.
The boys married nymphs( 仙女 ) and the girls married wood-gods and river-gods.
The lamp-post which the Witch( 女巫 ) had planted (without knowing it) shone day and night in the Narnian forest,
so that the place where it grew came to be called Lantern Waste;
and when, many years later, another child from our world got into Narnia, on a snowy night, she found the light still burning.
And that adventure was, in a way, connected with the ones I have just been telling you.
It was like this.
The tree which sprang from the Apple that Digory planted in the back garden, lived and grew into a fine tree.
Growing in the soil of our world, far out of the sound of Aslan’s voice and far from the young air of Narnia,
it did not bear apples that would revive( 使康复 ) a dying woman as Digory’s Mother had been revived( 使康复 ),
though it did bear apples more beautiful than any others in England, and they were extremely good for you, though not fully magical.
But inside itself, in the very sap( 树汁 ) of it, the tree (so to speak) never forgot that other tree in Narnia to which it belonged.
Sometimes it would move mysteriously when there was no wind blowing:

I think that when this happened there were high winds in Narnia and the English tree quivered( 抖动 ) because,at that moment, the Narnia tree was rocking and swaying( 摇摆 ) in a strong southwestern gale( 大风 ).
However that might be, it was proved later that there was still magic in its wood.
For when Digory was quite middle-aged (and he was a famous learned man, a Professor, and a great traveler by that time) and the Ketterleys’ old house belonged to( 属于 ) him,
there was a great storm all over the south of England which blew the tree down.
He couldn’t bear to have it simply chopped up( 劈 ) for firewood( 柴火 ), so he had part of the timber( 木料 ) made into a wardrobe( 衣柜 ), which he put in his big house in the country.
And though he himself did not discover the magic properties of that wardrobe( 衣柜 ), someone else did.
That was the beginning of all the comings and goings between Narnia and our world, which you can read of in other books.
When Digory and his people went to live in the big country house, they took Uncle Andrew to live with them;
for Digory’s Father said, “We must try to keep the old fellow out of mischief( 胡闹 ), and it isn’t fair that poor Letty should have him always on her hands.”
Uncle Andrew never tried any Magic again as long as he lived.
He had learned his lesson, and in his old age he became a nicer and less selfish old man than he had ever been before.
But he always liked to get visitors alone in the billiard-room( 桌球室 ) and tell them stories about a mysterious( 神秘的 ) lady, a foreign royalty, with whom he had driven about London.
“A devilish( 坏的 ) temper( 脾气 ) she had,” he would say. “But she was a damn( 非常 ) fine woman, sir, a damn( 非常 ) fine woman.”

article_info.previous: 在与Aslan交谈时，Digory坦白了他内心的挣扎，以及想要治好母亲的迫切心情。令他意外的是，Aslan竟然允许自己摘下苹果带给母亲。告别之际，Aslan给了孩子们一个警告，一个命令，Digory和Polly终于回到了现实世界。

article_info.share_words: And no sooner had she finished it than she smiled and her head sank back on the pillow and she was asleep: a real, natural, gentle, sleep, without any of those nasty drugs, which was, as Digory knew, the thing in the whole world that she wanted most.

question.cn: 什么东西被Digory埋在了后院？
question.en: What was buried by Digory in the back garden?

analysis: 文中提到“That evening he buried the core of the Apple in the back garden.”由此可知，Digroy把苹果核埋在了后院里，因此选C。

question.cn: Digroy的妈妈吃了苹果之后，变得怎么样？
question.en: How was Digory’s mother after she ate the apple?

analysis: 文中提到：“About a week after this it was quite certain that Digory's Mother was getting better. About a fortnight later she was able to sit out in the garden.”可知Digory的妈妈慢慢康复了，所以选B。

question.cn: 六周后，Digory收到了谁的来信？
question.en: After six weeks, whose letter did Digory receive?

analysis: 文中提到：“After about six weeks of this lovely life there came a long letter from Father in India， which had wonderful news in it.”由此可见，Digory收到了远在印度的父亲的来信，因此选A。

question.cn: 纳尼亚的动物们生活得怎么样？
question.en: How was the Beasts’ life in Narnia?

options.cn: 纳尼亚的动物们平静而快乐地生活着。
options.en: They lived in great peace and joy.

options.cn: 纳尼亚的动物们平淡地生活着。
纳尼亚的动物们悲伤地生活着。

analysis: 文中提到：“In Narnia the Beasts lived in great peace and joy and neither the Witch nor any other enemy came in trouble. . . ” 由此可知，动物们现在在纳尼亚的生活得非常平静快乐，因此选A。

question.cn: 苹果树被暴风雨吹倒之后，被做成了什么东西？
question.en: What was the apple tree made into after a storm blew it down?

analysis: 文中提到“He couldn’t bear to have it simply chopped up for firewood, so he had part of the timber made into a wardrobe, which he put in his big house in the country.”由此可知，一场暴风雨把苹果树吹倒了，Digory把苹果树原木做成了一个衣橱，因此选B。

question.cn: Polly第一次触碰到戒指时，发生了什么事？
question.en: What happened to Polly when she touched the ring for the first time?

analysis: 文中提到：“ Polly's hand went out to touch one of the rings. And immediately, without a flash or a noise or a warning of any sort, there was no Polly. ”由此可知，Polly消失了，因此选B。

question.cn: 狮子叫什么名字？
question.en: What was the name of the Lion?

analysis: 通过全篇剧情，我们得知狮子的名字叫Aslan，因此选B。

question.cn: 是谁给Uncle Andrew小盒子的？
question.en: Who gave Uncle Andrew the little box?

analysis: 文中提到：“She was my godmother. . . She gave it to me and made me promise that as soon as she was dead I would burn it.”由此可知，是Uncle Andrew的教母把小盒子给他，让他销毁掉，因此选C。

question.cn: Digory摘下苹果并将它带给Aslan了吗？
question.en: Did Digory pluck the apple and bring it back to Aslan?

analysis: Digory说道：“ I’ve brought you the apple you wanted, sir.”说明Digory已经成功完成了Aslan给予他的任务，把银苹果带给了Aslan，因此选A。

question.cn: 谁是纳尼亚第一任国王和王后？
question.en: Who were Narnia’s first King and Queen?

analysis: 文中提到：“When the crowns had been cooled in the river Aslan made Frank and Helen kneel before him and placed the crowns on their heads.”由此可知是Frank和Helen成为了纳尼亚第一任的国王和王后，因此选A。

question.cn: Digory长大之后的工作是什么？
question.en: What was Digory’s job after he grew up?

options.cn: 他是一位教授和旅行家。
options.en: He was a professor and traveler.

analysis: 文中提到：“For when Digory was quite middle-aged(and he was a famous learned man, a Professor, and a great traveler by that time).”由此得知Digory长大后成为了一名很有学识的人，成为了教授和旅行家，因此选B。

question.cn: 哪种水果治好了Digory的妈妈？
question.en: Which fruit healed Digory’s mother?

analysis: 根据剧情，Aslan允许Digory摘下苹果带回给他的妈妈，他一回家就把苹果给他妈妈吃了，第二天医生就说，他妈妈已经在渐渐康复，因此选C。

question.cn: 当Digory摘了银苹果之后，谁引诱了Digory?
question.en: Who tempted Digory after he picked the silver apple in the garden?

analysis: 在Digory摘下银苹果之后，女巫就出现在他面前，引诱他，因此选A。

question.cn: 谁建立了纳尼亚？
question.en: Who created Narnia?

analysis: 根据原文信息，纳尼亚是通过狮子Aslan的歌声创造出来的，因此选B。

question.cn: 谁唤醒了大厅里的女巫？
question.en: Who awoke the Witch in the hall?

analysis: 根据文中的描述，我们知道是Digory用锤子敲响钟，唤醒了沉睡的女巫，因此选B。

question.cn: Digory和Polly在阁楼里遇见了谁？
question.en: Whom did Digory and Polly meet in the attic?

analysis: Polly和Digory去空屋的小阁楼上探险，发现Uncle Andrew在阁楼里，因此选B。

question.cn: 以下关于戒指的描述中哪一项是正确的？
question.en: Which of the following statements about the rings is correct?

options.cn: 一些是黄色的，一些是绿色的。
options.en: Some were yellow and others were green.

analysis: Uncle Andrew制作的戒指，分别是黄色和绿色，因此选C。

question.cn: 女巫是否去过现实世界？
question.en: Had the Witch ever been to the real world?

analysis: 根据剧情我们知道，当Digory把女巫唤醒了之后，女巫就跟随两个孩子回到了现实世界，因此选A。

question.cn: 衣柜是由什么做成的？
question.en: What was the wardrobe made of?

options.en: It was made of the timber of the apple tree.
It was made of the timber of the peach tree.
It was made of the timber of the pear tree.

analysis: 在小说的结尾，从纳尼亚带回来的苹果树给Digory的妈妈吃了之后，果核被种在了院子里，长成了一棵苹果树，但是一场暴风雨把苹果树吹倒了，Digory觉得把它劈成柴火比较可惜，所以就决定用苹果树的木材做了衣柜，因此选A。

question.cn: 纳尼亚的冒险结束后，Digory怎样处理了戒指？
question.en: How did Digory deal with the rings after his adventure to Narnia?

options.en: He gave the rings to Polly.

analysis: Digory一行人回到现实世界后，遵循了Aslan的命令，以防戒指再一次被利用，所以把戒指埋在了地下，因此选A。

question.cn: Digory在花园摘取的苹果是什么颜色？
question.en: What was the color of the apple that Digory plucked in the garden?

analysis: 文中提到，当Digory走进门，一眼就知道哪棵树是正确的苹果树，因为上面苹果的颜色是银色的，因此Digory顺利摘到了银苹果，答案选C。

question.cn: 哪种动物驮着Digory和Polly去完成他们的使命？
question.en: Which animal took Digory and Polly to accomplish their mission?

analysis: 文中是Aslan赋予“草莓”这匹马一对翅膀，驮着二人去摘苹果，完成自己的使命，因此选A。

question.cn: 那封信中带来了什么信息？
question.en: What was the news that the letter contained?

analysis: Digory父亲的来信内容是说他继承了一笔不菲的遗产，变得非常的富有，而且准备回国，再也不离开他了，因此选B。

question.cn: 故事的结尾，Digory后来过上了怎样的生活？
question.en: At the end of the story, what kind of life did Digory live later？

analysis: 在小说的结尾，我们知道Digory的母亲吃了苹果痊愈，他的父亲意外地继承了一大笔财富，从此他们过上了幸福的生活，因此选A。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第44天
